## Friday's Name and Christian Symbolism

Robinson Crusoe names the man Friday, with whom he cannot at first communicate, because they first meet on that day. However, the naming carries deeper religious and symbolic significance beyond mere commemoration of their meeting day.

### Good Friday Connection

While the search results don't explicitly mention a direct connection to Good Friday, the timing and context suggest symbolic parallels. Crusoe teaches Friday the English language and converts him to Christianity. This conversion process becomes central to the novel's religious themes.

### Christian Salvation Themes

The relationship between Crusoe and Friday serves as an allegory for Christian salvation and redemption. Crusoe works to give Friday a "new soul" by imposing European customs and Christianity, viewing him as a "savage" needing civilization.(no content)Though Crusoe seems to struggle with his own faith and how it dictates the events of his life, he seems to believe that bringing Friday to the knowledge of the Christian God will save his life and his soul.

### Religious Transformation

The novel portrays Friday's conversion as spiritually significant. It was remarkable, too, I had but three subjects, and they were of three different religions - my man Friday was a Protestant, his father was a Pagan and a cannibal, and the Spaniard was a Papist. This transformation from paganism to Protestant Christianity mirrors the broader theme of spiritual salvation.

### Broader Religious Allegory

A leitmotif of the novel is the Christian notion of providence, penitence, and redemption. Friday's salvation becomes part of Crusoe's own spiritual journey. Notice that the religious journey Defoe documents in Robinson Crusoe is deepened by his sharing of his faith with another individual.

The naming of Friday, while literally based on the day of their meeting, functions symbolically within the novel's Christian framework, representing themes of salvation, conversion, and divine providence that were central to Defoe's religious worldview.
